concepts.name: Line symmetry and rotational symmetry of 2-D shapes
Reflection of points and shapes in a line (mirror line)
Rotation of shapes about a point through a given angle

questions.question_text: How many lines of symmetry does an equilateral triangle have?
questions.explanation_correct: An equilateral triangle has 3 equal sides and 3 equal angles. Because of this symmetry, an equilateral triangle has 3 lines of symmetry.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect option is D) 6 lines of symmetry. An equilateral triangle is a regular polygon with 3 sides. Regular polygons have n lines of symmetry, where n is the number of sides. Therefore, an equilateral triangle has 3 lines of symmetry, not 6.

questions.question_text: What is the order of rotational symmetry of a square?
questions.explanation_correct: The order of rotational symmetry of a square is 4. This means that a square can be rotated by 90°, 180°, 270°, or 360° and it will look the same. The square has 4 rotational symmetries, so the correct answer is B.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The order of rotational symmetry of a square is not 2, 6, or 8. A square has 4 rotational symmetries, where it looks the same after rotating by 90°, 180°, 270°, or 360°. Options A, C, and D are incorrect because they do not represent the actual number of rotational symmetries of a square.

questions.question_text: A circle has infinite lines of symmetry.
questions.explanation_correct: A circle has infinite lines of symmetry because any line passing through the center of the circle will divide the circle into two equal halves. This means that a circle can be folded in any direction along its center and the two halves will exactly match each other, indicating that a circle has an infinite number of lines of symmetry.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A common misconception is that a circle has a finite number of lines of symmetry. This is not true. A circle can be divided into equal halves along any line passing through its center, so it has an infinite number of lines of symmetry. The correct answer is that a circle has infinite lines of symmetry.

questions.question_text: How many lines of symmetry does a regular pentagon have?
questions.explanation_correct: A regular pentagon has 5 equal sides and 5 equal angles. Since it has 5 equal sides, it has 5 lines of symmetry, one passing through each side of the pentagon.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A regular pentagon does not have 3 or 4 lines of symmetry. It also does not have 10 lines of symmetry. A regular pentagon has 5 lines of symmetry because it has 5 equal sides, and each line of symmetry passes through the midpoint of one of the sides.

questions.question_text: A rectangle has _____ lines of symmetry.
questions.explanation_correct: A rectangle has 2 lines of symmetry because it can be divided into two equal halves by drawing a vertical line down the center or a horizontal line across the center. This means the two halves are identical or 'symmetrical' to each other.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 2 lines of symmetry. Some students may think a rectangle has 4 lines of symmetry, but this is not correct. A rectangle only has 2 lines of symmetry - one vertical line down the center and one horizontal line across the center. It does not have diagonal lines of symmetry.

questions.question_text: When a point is reflected across a vertical mirror line, which coordinate changes?
questions.explanation_correct: When a point is reflected across a vertical mirror line, only the x-coordinate of the point changes, while the y-coordinate remains the same. This is because a vertical mirror line reflects points only along the horizontal axis, leaving the vertical axis unchanged.
questions.explanation_incorrect: When a point is reflected across a vertical mirror line, the y-coordinate does not change. This is because the vertical mirror line only affects the horizontal, or x-coordinate, of the point. The y-coordinate remains the same after the reflection. Therefore, option A is the correct answer.

questions.question_text: An isosceles triangle has exactly 1 line of symmetry.
questions.explanation_correct: An isosceles triangle has two sides of equal length, which means it has a line of symmetry that passes through the vertex opposite the equal sides and bisects the base. Therefore, an isosceles triangle has exactly 1 line of symmetry.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Some students may think that an isosceles triangle has no line of symmetry because it is not a regular polygon. However, the two equal sides of an isosceles triangle create a line of symmetry that passes through the vertex opposite the equal sides and bisects the base. An isosceles triangle does not have multiple lines of symmetry like an equilateral triangle, but it has exactly one line of symmetry.

questions.question_text: What angle of rotation brings a shape back to its original position?
questions.explanation_correct: The angle of rotation that brings a shape back to its original position is 360°. This is because a full rotation of 360 degrees takes the shape back to its starting point, without changing its orientation.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The other options are incorrect because they do not fully rotate the shape back to its original position. 90° and 270° are partial rotations, while 180° flips the shape over, but does not return it to the original orientation.

questions.question_text: A regular hexagon has _____ lines of symmetry.
questions.explanation_correct: A regular hexagon has 6 lines of symmetry because it has 6 equal sides and 6 equal angles. This means that the hexagon can be folded along 6 different lines and the two halves will match perfectly.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A regular hexagon does not have 4 lines of symmetry. A regular hexagon has 6 lines of symmetry, as it is a 6-sided polygon with 6 equal sides and 6 equal angles. The correct answer is 6 lines of symmetry.

questions.question_text: Which letter of the alphabet has both horizontal and vertical lines of symmetry?
questions.explanation_correct: The letter X has both horizontal and vertical lines of symmetry, meaning it can be divided into two equal halves along both the horizontal and vertical axes. This makes X the only letter option given that has this property of double symmetry.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The letters A, B, and H do not have both horizontal and vertical lines of symmetry. A and H have only one line of symmetry (vertical), while B has no lines of symmetry at all. Only the letter X out of the given options can be divided into equal halves along both the horizontal and vertical axes, making it the correct answer.

questions.question_text: A rotation of 180° about the center of a rectangle maps it onto itself.
questions.explanation_correct: A rotation of 180° about the center of a rectangle maps it onto itself because a 180° rotation flips the rectangle over, making it look the same as before the rotation.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A rotation of 180° about the center of a rectangle does not map it onto itself. This is because a 180° rotation would flip the rectangle over, making it look different from the original. The correct answer is that a 180° rotation of a rectangle about its center does map it onto itself.

questions.question_text: What is the order of rotational symmetry of a regular octagon?
questions.explanation_correct: A regular octagon has 8 sides and 8 angles. It can be rotated 8 times around its center and look exactly the same, so the order of rotational symmetry of a regular octagon is 8.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The order of rotational symmetry of a shape is the number of times it can be rotated around its center and look exactly the same. Since a regular octagon has 8 sides and 8 angles, it can be rotated 8 times and still look the same. Options A, B, and D do not correctly represent the order of rotational symmetry for a regular octagon.

questions.question_text: A parallelogram (that is not a rectangle) has _____ lines of symmetry.
questions.explanation_correct: A parallelogram (that is not a rectangle) does not have any lines of symmetry. This is because a parallelogram has two pairs of parallel sides, but the sides are not equal in length, so the shape is not symmetric about any line.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The accepted answer is '0' lines of symmetry. A parallelogram that is not a rectangle does not have any lines of symmetry. This is because the sides are not equal in length, and the angles are not right angles. Therefore, the shape is not symmetric about any line. The correct answer is 0 lines of symmetry.

questions.question_text: When a shape is reflected in a mirror line, the mirror line acts as a line of:
questions.explanation_correct: When a shape is reflected in a mirror line, the mirror line acts as a line of symmetry. This means that the reflected shape is an exact mirror image of the original shape, with the mirror line acting as the axis of reflection.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The mirror line does not act as a line of rotation or translation. Rotation involves turning a shape around a fixed point, while translation involves moving a shape to a new position without changing its orientation. The mirror line is the axis of symmetry, where the reflected shape is an exact mirror image of the original shape.

questions.question_text: A scalene triangle has no lines of symmetry.
questions.explanation_correct: A scalene triangle has no lines of symmetry because all its sides and angles are different. This means the triangle cannot be divided into two identical halves by any line passing through it.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Some students may think that a scalene triangle has lines of symmetry because it looks like an irregular shape. However, this is not true. A scalene triangle has no lines of symmetry because all its sides and angles are unequal, so the triangle cannot be divided into two identical halves by any line.

questions.question_text: By what angle must a square be rotated about its center to map onto itself for the first time?
questions.explanation_correct: A square has four sides of equal length and four right angles (90 degrees). To map a square onto itself, it must be rotated by 90 degrees about its center, since a 90 degree rotation will bring the square back to its original position.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A square has 4 sides of equal length and 4 right angles (90 degrees). Rotating it by 45 degrees would not map it onto itself, as the corners would not align with the original position. Rotating it by 180 degrees or 360 degrees would also not be the first time it maps onto itself, as these angles are multiples of 90 degrees.

questions.question_text: The order of rotational symmetry of a regular polygon with n sides is _____.
questions.explanation_correct: The order of rotational symmetry of a regular polygon with n sides is n. This is because a regular polygon with n sides can be rotated through an angle of 360°/n and still look the same, meaning it has n distinct orientations that are indistinguishable from the original.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The order of rotational symmetry of a regular polygon with n sides is not 1. A common misconception is that the order of rotational symmetry is always 1, but this is not the case for regular polygons. The correct answer is n, as a regular polygon with n sides can be rotated through an angle of 360°/n and still look the same, meaning it has n distinct orientations that are indistinguishable from the original.

questions.question_text: A rhombus (that is not a square) has how many lines of symmetry?
questions.explanation_correct: A rhombus (that is not a square) has 2 lines of symmetry. This is because a rhombus has 2 pairs of parallel sides that are equal in length, so it can be folded in half along its diagonals to create 2 identical halves.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is C) 2 lines of symmetry. A rhombus has 4 sides of equal length, but it is not a square. This means it has 2 lines of symmetry where it can be folded in half to create 2 identical halves. It does not have 0 or 4 lines of symmetry, as those would be for other shapes like a parallelogram or a square.

questions.question_text: If point A(3, 5) is reflected across a horizontal mirror line at y = 2, what are the coordinates of the reflected point?
questions.explanation_correct: The point A(3, 5) is reflected across a horizontal mirror line at y = 2. This means that the y-coordinate of the reflected point will be the same distance below the mirror line as the original point is above it. So, the y-coordinate of the reflected point becomes 2 - (5 - 2) = -1, while the x-coordinate remains the same at 3.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option A, (3, -1), is the correct answer. The point A(3, 5) is reflected across a horizontal mirror line at y = 2, which means that the new y-coordinate is the same distance below the mirror line as the original point is above it. Option B, (3, -5), is incorrect because the new y-coordinate should be -1, not -5. Option C, (3, 0), is incorrect because the new y-coordinate should be -1, not 0. Option D, (-3, 5), is incorrect because the x-coordinate of the reflected point should remain the same at 3, not change to -3.

questions.question_text: If a shape has rotational symmetry of order 6, it can be rotated by 60° to map onto itself.
questions.explanation_correct: If a shape has rotational symmetry of order 6, it means the shape can be rotated by 60° (360° divided by 6) and still look the same. This is because 60° is the smallest angle through which the shape can be rotated and still map onto itself.
questions.explanation_incorrect: If the shape had rotational symmetry of order 3, it could be rotated by 120° (360° divided by 3) and still map onto itself. However, for a shape with rotational symmetry of order 6, the smallest angle through which it can be rotated and still look the same is 60°, not 120°.

questions.question_text: Which of these capital letters has exactly 2 lines of symmetry?
questions.explanation_correct: The capital letter 'I' has exactly 2 lines of symmetry - one vertical line of symmetry down the center and one horizontal line of symmetry through the middle.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The capital letter 'E' has 3 lines of symmetry, the capital letter 'H' has 2 lines of symmetry, and the capital letter 'O' has infinitely many lines of symmetry. So the correct answer is 'I', which has exactly 2 lines of symmetry.

questions.question_text: When a point is reflected across a horizontal mirror line, the _____ coordinate remains unchanged.
questions.explanation_correct: When a point is reflected across a horizontal mirror line, the x-coordinate of the point remains the same. This is because a horizontal mirror line only affects the vertical (y) coordinate, leaving the horizontal (x) coordinate unchanged.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The y-coordinate remains unchanged when a point is reflected across a horizontal mirror line. This is because a horizontal mirror line is parallel to the x-axis, so it only affects the vertical (y) position of the point. The correct answer format is 'x', as the x-coordinate is the one that remains the same after a horizontal reflection.

questions.question_text: A regular polygon has 9 lines of symmetry. How many sides does it have?
questions.explanation_correct: A regular polygon with 9 lines of symmetry must have 9 sides. This is because a regular polygon with n sides has n lines of symmetry, so a 9-sided regular polygon has 9 lines of symmetry.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 9 sides. A regular polygon with n sides has n lines of symmetry. So a regular polygon with 6 sides would have 6 lines of symmetry, not 9. Similarly, a regular polygon with 12 or 18 sides would have 12 or 18 lines of symmetry, not 9.

questions.question_text: An equilateral triangle rotated 120° about its center will map onto itself.
questions.explanation_correct: An equilateral triangle has 120° angles, so rotating it by 120° about its center will make it map onto itself. This is because the triangle will return to its original position after the 120° rotation.
questions.explanation_incorrect: An equilateral triangle has 120° angles, so rotating it by 120° about its center will not map onto itself. Many students may think that the triangle will not return to its original position, but this is not the case. The 120° rotation will make the triangle map perfectly onto itself, as the angles of an equilateral triangle are multiples of 120°.

questions.question_text: A kite has how many lines of symmetry?
questions.explanation_correct: A kite has one line of symmetry. This means that if you fold the kite along a certain line, the two halves will match perfectly. The line that divides the kite into two identical halves is called the line of symmetry.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A kite does not have 0 lines of symmetry, as that would mean the two halves of the kite do not match at all. It also does not have 2 or 4 lines of symmetry, as a kite has only one line that divides it into two identical halves. Therefore, option B, which states that a kite has 1 line of symmetry, is the correct answer.

questions.question_text: If a regular pentagon is rotated 72° about its center, it will map onto itself because 360°/_____ = 72°.
questions.explanation_correct: A regular pentagon has 5 sides and 5 corners. When it is rotated 72° (360° divided by 5), it will map exactly onto itself because the rotation angle is a factor of 360°.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 5. This is because a regular pentagon has 5 sides, and when it is rotated by 360° divided by the number of sides, it will map onto itself. In this case, 360° divided by 5 is 72°, so the pentagon will map onto itself when rotated by 72°.

questions.question_text: A triangle with vertices at A, B, and C is reflected across a vertical line. Which of these properties is NOT preserved?
questions.explanation_correct: The orientation (clockwise/counterclockwise) of the triangle is not preserved when it is reflected across a vertical line. Reflection flips the direction of the triangle, so it will change from clockwise to counterclockwise or vice versa.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The size of the angles, the lengths of the sides, and the shape of the triangle are all preserved when reflecting a triangle across a vertical line. This is because reflection is an isometry, meaning it preserves the overall geometry of the shape. However, the orientation (clockwise/counterclockwise) of the triangle will change, as reflection flips the direction of the shape.

questions.question_text: A regular heptagon (7 sides) has rotational symmetry of order 7.
questions.explanation_correct: A regular heptagon (7 sides) has rotational symmetry of order 7 because when you rotate the heptagon by 360/7 degrees, the shape looks exactly the same. This means that the heptagon has 7 different rotational positions where it looks the same, so the rotational symmetry order is 7.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A common mistake is to think that a regular heptagon has rotational symmetry of order 6, since it has 6 sides. However, the rotational symmetry order is determined by the number of times the shape looks the same when rotated, not the number of sides. Since a regular heptagon has 7 identical positions when rotated, its rotational symmetry order is 7.

questions.question_text: Which shape has infinite order of rotational symmetry?
questions.explanation_correct: The circle has infinite order of rotational symmetry because it can be rotated by any angle and still look the same. This means the circle can be rotated any number of times and it will always look exactly the same.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The square, regular hexagon, and equilateral triangle do not have infinite order of rotational symmetry. They can only be rotated by specific angles and still look the same. For example, a square can be rotated by 90, 180, 270, or 360 degrees and still look the same. The circle, on the other hand, can be rotated by any angle and still look the same, which is why it has infinite order of rotational symmetry.

questions.question_text: The perpendicular distance from a point to a mirror line equals the perpendicular distance from the mirror line to its _____.
questions.explanation_correct: The perpendicular distance from a point to a mirror line is equal to the perpendicular distance from the mirror line to the reflection of that point. This is because when an object is reflected in a mirror, the distance between the object and the mirror is the same as the distance between the mirror and the reflection.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The accepted answer format is 'reflection'. The correct answer is 'reflection' because when an object is reflected in a mirror, the distance between the object and the mirror is the same as the distance between the mirror and the reflection. This is a property of reflection that helps us determine the location of the reflection.

questions.question_text: A rectangle is rotated 90° clockwise about its center. If it does not map onto itself, what can we conclude?
questions.explanation_correct: If a rectangle is rotated 90° clockwise and it does not map onto itself, it means the rectangle is not a square. A square has rotational symmetry of 90°, but a rectangle does not.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is B) It is not a square. A square has rotational symmetry of 90°, which means it looks the same after a 90° clockwise rotation. If the rectangle does not map onto itself after a 90° rotation, it means it is not a square. It could have other properties, such as no rotational symmetry or 4 lines of symmetry, but the key point is that it is not a square.

questions.question_text: Every regular polygon has at least one line of symmetry.
questions.explanation_correct: Every regular polygon has at least one line of symmetry because the sides and angles of a regular polygon are all equal. This means that the polygon can be folded exactly in half, with one side matching the other. This line of symmetry is a line that divides the polygon into two identical halves.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Some students may think that not all regular polygons have a line of symmetry, but this is not true. All regular polygons, such as squares, triangles, pentagons, and so on, have at least one line of symmetry. The key is that the sides and angles of a regular polygon are all equal, allowing the polygon to be folded in half and creating a line of symmetry.

questions.question_text: What is the smallest angle of rotation for a regular decagon (10 sides) to map onto itself?
questions.explanation_correct: The smallest angle of rotation for a regular decagon (10 sides) to map onto itself is 36°. This is because a regular decagon has 10 sides, and dividing 360° (the full rotation) by 10 gives 36°, which is the angle needed to map the decagon onto itself.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option A (30°) is incorrect because a regular decagon has 10 sides, and the angle needed to map it onto itself is 36°, not 30°. Option C (45°) and Option D (60°) are also incorrect because they do not match the 36° angle required for a decagon.

questions.question_text: The letter _____ has both line symmetry and rotational symmetry of order 2.
questions.explanation_correct: The letter H has both line symmetry and rotational symmetry of order 2 (180-degree rotation). This means that the letter H can be folded in half along a vertical line and it will look the same, and it can also be rotated 180 degrees and it will look the same.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The letter H has both line symmetry and rotational symmetry, which means that it can be folded in half along a line and it will look the same, and it can also be rotated and it will look the same. The correct answer is H, as this is the only letter that has both line symmetry and rotational symmetry of order 2 (180-degree rotation).

questions.question_text: A regular polygon has an order of rotational symmetry of 12. (a) How many sides does the polygon have? (b) How many lines of symmetry does it have? (c) What is the smallest angle of rotation that maps it onto itself?
questions.explanation_correct: A regular polygon with an order of rotational symmetry of 12 must have 12 sides, since each rotation of 30° (360°/12) maps the polygon onto itself. This means it has 12 lines of symmetry, one for each side of the polygon.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The accepted answer format is (a) 12 sides (b) 12 lines of symmetry (c) 30°. A common misconception could be that the number of sides is equal to the order of rotational symmetry, but this is not always the case. The order of rotational symmetry is 12, which means the polygon can be rotated by 30° (360°/12) and still look the same.

questions.correct_answer: (a) 5 units to the left and 3 units above the mirror line (b) 10 units
questions.question_text: Point P is located 5 units to the right and 3 units above a vertical mirror line. (a) Where is the reflected point P' located relative to the mirror line? (b) If the distance between P and P' is measured, what would it be?
questions.explanation_correct: The reflected point P' is located 5 units to the left and 3 units above the mirror line because in a reflection, the distance from the mirror line is the same for both the original point and the reflected point. The distance between P and P' is 10 units because the total distance traveled is twice the distance from the mirror line.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer format is: (a) 5 units to the left and 3 units above the mirror line (b) 10 units. Some students may think the reflected point is located in a different position, but in a reflection, the distance from the mirror line is the same for both the original point and the reflected point. The distance between P and P' is 10 units because the total distance traveled is twice the distance from the mirror line.

questions.question_text: A regular hexagon ABCDEF is rotated 120° clockwise about its center O. (a) Which vertex moves to the position originally occupied by vertex A? (b) How many times would this rotation need to be applied to return the hexagon to its original position?
questions.explanation_correct: A regular hexagon has 6 vertices, and rotating it 120° clockwise means each vertex moves to the position of the vertex 2 spaces to the right. So, vertex A moves to the position of vertex C. Additionally, since a full rotation of 360° returns the hexagon to its original position, and 360° is evenly divisible by 120°, the hexagon will return to its original position after 3 rotations of 120° clockwise.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect answer would be to say that vertex B moves to the position originally occupied by vertex A. This is not correct because a 120° clockwise rotation means each vertex moves 2 spaces to the right, not 1 space to the right. The correct answer is that vertex C moves to the position originally occupied by vertex A. Also, the hexagon would need to be rotated 3 times by 120° clockwise to return to its original position, not just 1 time.

questions.question_text: Consider a regular pentagon. (a) State the order of rotational symmetry. (b) Find the angle of rotation that maps the pentagon onto itself for the second time. (c) How many lines of symmetry does it have?
questions.explanation_correct: The answer is correct because a regular pentagon has 5 sides and 5 vertices, so it has a rotational symmetry of order 5. The angle of rotation that maps the pentagon onto itself for the second time is 360°/5 = 144°. And a regular pentagon has 5 lines of symmetry, one passing through each vertex and the midpoint of the opposite side.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The accepted answer format is (a) 5 (b) 144° (c) 5. The incorrect explanation would be: A regular pentagon has a rotational symmetry of order 4, not 5. The angle of rotation that maps the pentagon onto itself for the second time is 360°/4 = 90°, not 144°. And a regular pentagon has 4 lines of symmetry, not 5.

questions.correct_answer: In a regular polygon with odd sides, there is no vertex directly opposite to any vertex. Therefore, each line of symmetry must pass through a vertex and the midpoint of the opposite side to maintain equal division.
questions.question_text: Explain why a regular polygon with an odd number of sides has all its lines of symmetry passing through a vertex and the midpoint of the opposite side.
questions.explanation_correct: In a regular polygon with an odd number of sides, there is no vertex directly opposite to any other vertex. Therefore, each line of symmetry must pass through a vertex and the midpoint of the opposite side in order to maintain equal division and balance the polygon.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A common mistake is to think that the lines of symmetry in a regular polygon with odd sides would pass through the vertices only. However, this is not the case. Since there is no vertex directly opposite to any other vertex, the lines of symmetry must pass through a vertex and the midpoint of the opposite side in order to maintain the equal division and balance of the polygon.

questions.correct_answer: (a) A'(2, 2), B'(6, 2), C'(4, 5) (b) Yes, reflection preserves size and shape, creating congruent figures.
questions.question_text: Triangle ABC has vertices A(2, 4), B(6, 4), and C(4, 1). The triangle is reflected across the horizontal line y = 3. (a) Find the coordinates of the reflected vertices A', B', and C'. (b) Is the reflected triangle congruent to the original? Explain.
questions.explanation_correct: The reflected vertices A', B', and C' are found by flipping the original x-coordinates across the horizontal line y = 3. This preserves the size and shape of the original triangle, creating a congruent reflected figure.
questions.explanation_incorrect: To find the reflected vertices, you need to flip the y-coordinates across the horizontal line y = 3. The correct coordinates are: A'(2, 2), B'(6, 2), and C'(4, 5). The reflected triangle is congruent to the original because reflection is a rigid transformation that preserves size and shape.

questions.correct_answer: (a) Yes, 90° clockwise (b) P moves to the position originally occupied by vertex S (one position clockwise).
questions.question_text: A square PQRS is rotated 270° counterclockwise about its center. (a) Is this equivalent to any clockwise rotation? If so, what angle? (b) Describe the position of vertex P after this rotation.
questions.explanation_correct: A 270° counterclockwise rotation is equivalent to a 90° clockwise rotation, since they both move the square the same way. After this rotation, the vertex P will move to the position originally occupied by vertex S, which is one position clockwise.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The question asks for the equivalent clockwise rotation and the new position of vertex P after a 270° counterclockwise rotation. The accepted answer is that the equivalent clockwise rotation is 90° and vertex P moves to the position originally occupied by vertex S (one position clockwise). This is correct because a 270° counterclockwise rotation is the same as a 90° clockwise rotation, and the vertex P will move one position clockwise to the original position of vertex S.

questions.question_text: A regular octagon has vertices labeled 1 through 8. (a) What is the order of rotational symmetry? (b) If the octagon is rotated 135° about its center, which numbered vertex will be at the position originally occupied by vertex 1? (c) How many lines of symmetry pass through opposite vertices?
questions.explanation_correct: The order of rotational symmetry of a regular octagon is 8 because the octagon can be rotated 45°, 90°, 135°, 180°, 225°, 270°, 315°, or 360° to look the same. When rotated 135° about its center, vertex 4 will be in the position originally occupied by vertex 1. A regular octagon has 4 lines of symmetry passing through opposite vertices.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect answer would be to say the order of rotational symmetry is 4, that vertex 5 will be at the position of vertex 1 after a 135° rotation, and that there are 8 lines of symmetry. This is wrong because a regular octagon has 8 rotational symmetries, vertex 4 will be at the position of vertex 1 after a 135° rotation, and there are 4 lines of symmetry passing through opposite vertices.

questions.correct_answer: (a) 2 (b) Yes, order 2 (c) Yes, it would have 4 lines of symmetry and rotational symmetry of order 4.
questions.question_text: A rectangle ABCD has length 8 cm and width 4 cm. (a) How many lines of symmetry does it have? (b) Does it have rotational symmetry? If yes, what is the order? (c) Would your answers change if the length and width were equal?
questions.explanation_correct: A rectangle has 2 lines of symmetry - one along the length and one along the width. It has rotational symmetry of order 2, meaning it can be rotated 180 degrees and still look the same. If the length and width were equal, it would have 4 lines of symmetry (along the diagonals as well) and rotational symmetry of order 4.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The accepted answer format is: (a) 2 (b) Yes, order 2 (c) Yes, it would have 4 lines of symmetry and rotational symmetry of order 4. If the length and width were equal, the rectangle would have more lines of symmetry and a higher order of rotational symmetry, as mentioned in part (c) of the correct answer.

questions.correct_answer: (a) The shape returns to its original position. (b) The identity transformation (no change).
questions.question_text: A shape is reflected across a vertical mirror line, and then the image is reflected again across the same line. (a) Describe the final position of the shape. (b) What single transformation is equivalent to two reflections across the same line?
questions.explanation_correct: The shape returns to its original position after two reflections across the same line because a reflection across a vertical line is equivalent to a rotation of 180 degrees. Performing two such reflections effectively cancels out the transformation, leaving the shape in its original position.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is: (a) The shape returns to its original position, and (b) The identity transformation (no change). This is because a reflection across a line followed by another reflection across the same line is equivalent to no change at all, as the two reflections cancel each other out, leaving the shape in its original position. Two reflections across the same line is the same as doing no transformation, which is known as the identity transformation.
